\doxysubsubsection{\texorpdfstring{Cmap}{Cmap}}
{\footnotesize\ttfamily enum \mbox{\hyperlink{namespacehmap_ac70fe3cbb32e0340d5dd3e15cdcf9369}{hmap\+::\+Cmap}} \+: int}



Enumeration for different colormap types. 

Enumeration of colormap types for image processing.

This enumeration is defined in the highmap/colormap.\+hpp file and is used for selecting the colormap to be applied during colorization.

This enumeration defines various colormap options that can be used for visualizing data in image processing. Each colormap provides a different color mapping scheme, which can be applied to grayscale images or data to enhance visual interpretation. \begin{DoxyEnumFields}{Enumerator}

Enumeration for different kernel functions used in various algorithms. 

This enumeration defines the types of kernel functions that can be used for smoothing, interpolation, and other operations requiring a kernel. Each kernel type represents a specific mathematical function used to weight data points based on their distance from a central point.

Converts an Open\+CV {\ttfamily cv\+::\+Mat} to a 2D {\ttfamily \doxylink{classhmap_1_1Array}{Array}} with optional value scaling to \mbox{[}0, 1\mbox{]}. 

This function converts an Open\+CV {\ttfamily cv\+::\+Mat} object into a 2D {\ttfamily \doxylink{classhmap_1_1Array}{Array}}. The conversion process creates a new {\ttfamily \doxylink{classhmap_1_1Array}{Array}} object and copies the data from the {\ttfamily cv\+::\+Mat} into this {\ttfamily \doxylink{classhmap_1_1Array}{Array}}. If the {\ttfamily remap\+\_\+values} parameter is set to {\ttfamily true} (the default), the values in the resulting {\ttfamily \doxylink{classhmap_1_1Array}{Array}} will be scaled to the interval \mbox{[}0, 1\mbox{]}. If set to {\ttfamily false}, the values will be copied directly without scaling. Modifications to the {\ttfamily \doxylink{classhmap_1_1Array}{Array}} will not affect the original {\ttfamily cv\+::\+Mat} and vice versa.


\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em mat} & Reference to the Open\+CV {\ttfamily cv\+::\+Mat} object that will be converted. \\
\hline
{\em remap\+\_\+values} & A boolean flag indicating whether to scale the values to \mbox{[}0, 1\mbox{]}. If {\ttfamily true}, the values will be scaled; if {\ttfamily false}, they will be copied directly. Default is {\ttfamily true}. \\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}
\begin{DoxyReturn}{Returns}
A 2D {\ttfamily \doxylink{classhmap_1_1Array}{Array}} object containing a copy of the data from the input {\ttfamily cv\+::\+Mat}, with optional scaling to the interval \mbox{[}0, 1\mbox{]}.
\end{DoxyReturn}

Point-\/wise alteration\+: locally enforce a new elevation value while maintaining the \textquotesingle{}shape\textquotesingle{} of the heightmap. 

This function modifies the elevation values in the input array based on a cloud of points that specify the coordinates and variations for the alterations. The function ensures that the shape of the heightmap is preserved while applying these local changes.

The alteration is performed using a kernel with a minimal radius ({\ttfamily ir}) and the intensity of the alterations is scaled based on the {\ttfamily footprint\+\_\+ratio}. The {\ttfamily shift} parameter allows for introducing noise or offset in the alteration process, and the {\ttfamily scale} parameter is used to adjust the domain of the alteration.


\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em array} & Input array representing the heightmap to be altered. The elevation values in this array will be adjusted according to the cloud data. \\
\hline
{\em cloud} & \doxylink{classhmap_1_1Cloud}{Cloud} object that defines the coordinates and elevation variations for the alterations. This object provides the necessary data for applying the local changes. \\
\hline
{\em ir} & Alteration kernel minimal radius. This parameter defines the minimum size of the kernel used for local alterations. \\
\hline
{\em footprint\+\_\+ratio} & Defines how the radius of the alteration scales with the variation intensity. A higher ratio results in a larger footprint of the alterations. \\
\hline
{\em shift} & Noise shift specified as a vector \{xs, ys\} for each direction, relative to a unit domain. This allows for adding random offsets to the alteration process. \\
\hline
{\em scale} & Domain scaling in the range \mbox{[}0, 1\mbox{]}. This parameter adjusts the domain size over which the alteration is applied.\\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}

Generate a heightmap from a coarse grid of control points with defined elevation values. 

This function creates a heightmap by interpolating elevation values provided at specific control points on a coarse grid. The result is a finer resolution heightmap where the elevation values are smoothly distributed over the entire grid.

The interpolation is performed using a Gaussian function, with the {\ttfamily width\+\_\+factor} parameter controlling the half-\/width of the base Gaussian function used for smoothing. Optionally, noise can be added using the provided {\ttfamily p\+\_\+noise\+\_\+x} and {\ttfamily p\+\_\+noise\+\_\+y} arrays, and the heightmap can be adjusted by a local wavenumber multiplier specified by {\ttfamily p\+\_\+stretching}. The {\ttfamily bbox} parameter defines the domain bounding box for the heightmap.


\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em shape} & Dimensions of the output array (heightmap). \\
\hline
{\em values} & Elevation values at the control points specified on a coarse grid. This 2D vector holds the elevation data at each control point. \\
\hline
{\em width\+\_\+factor} & Factor applied to the half-\/width of the Gaussian function used for smoothing the elevations. A value of 1.\+0 represents the default smoothing width. \\
\hline
{\em p\+\_\+noise\+\_\+x} & Optional pointer to an input noise array affecting the x-\/direction. If provided, it is used to add noise to the elevation values. \\
\hline
{\em p\+\_\+noise\+\_\+y} & Optional pointer to an input noise array affecting the y-\/direction. If provided, it is used to add noise to the elevation values. \\
\hline
{\em p\+\_\+stretching} & Optional pointer to an input array that acts as a local wavenumber multiplier. If provided, it adjusts the elevation values according to the local wavenumber. \\
\hline
{\em bbox} & Domain bounding box specified as a vector \{xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax\}. This defines the extent of the heightmap in the coordinate space. \\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}
\begin{DoxyReturn}{Returns}
\doxylink{classhmap_1_1Array}{Array} A new array representing the generated heightmap with interpolated elevation values.

Apply the reverse midpoint displacement algorithm to the input array. 

This function implements the reverse midpoint displacement algorithm as described in Belhadj et al. (2005). The algorithm generates a terrain-\/like structure by applying displacement to the values in the input array based on random noise. The function can be tuned using the {\ttfamily seed} parameter for random number generation, {\ttfamily noise\+\_\+scale} for controlling the amplitude of the noise, and {\ttfamily threshold} for setting a background value.


\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em array} & Input array to which the reverse midpoint displacement algorithm will be applied. The array\textquotesingle{}s values are modified to produce the output terrain. \\
\hline
{\em seed} & Random seed number used to initialize the random number generator for reproducibility. \\
\hline
{\em noise\+\_\+scale} & Amplitude of the noise applied during the displacement process. A higher value results in more pronounced terrain features. \\
\hline
{\em threshold} & Threshold \textquotesingle{}background\textquotesingle{} value used to influence the displacement algorithm. Values below this threshold may be treated differently depending on the algorithm\textquotesingle{}s design. \\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}
\begin{DoxyReturn}{Returns}
\doxylink{classhmap_1_1Array}{Array} The output array after applying the reverse midpoint displacement algorithm. This array contains the modified values representing the generated terrain.
\end{DoxyReturn}

Generate a heightmap based on a set of ridgelines and a specified slope. 

This function creates a heightmap using a set of ridgelines defined by their x, y, and z coordinates, and applies a specified slope to the ridgelines. The function can optionally apply smoothing, adjust the ridge edge width, and clamp values below a minimum threshold. Generate a heightmap based on a set of ridgelines with quadratic Bezier interpolation. 

This function creates a heightmap using ridgelines defined by their x, y, and z coordinates. The ridgelines are interpolated using quadratic Bezier curves to smooth the transitions. The function applies a specified slope to the ridgelines and can optionally apply smoothing, adjust ridge edge width, and clamp values below a minimum threshold. Additional noise and stretching parameters can be used to modify the resulting heightmap.


\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em shape} & The dimensions of the output array (heightmap). \\
\hline
{\em xr} & A vector of x-\/coordinates defining ridge segments, organized in groups of three (control points of the Bezier curves). \\
\hline
{\em yr} & A vector of y-\/coordinates defining ridge segments, organized in groups of three (control points of the Bezier curves). \\
\hline
{\em zr} & A vector of z-\/coordinates defining ridge segments, organized in groups of three (control points of the Bezier curves). \\
\hline
{\em slope} & The slope applied to the ridgelines. Can be negative to invert the slope. \\
\hline
{\em k\+\_\+smoothing} & Smoothing parameter to control the smoothness of the ridgelines. \\
\hline
{\em width} & Width of the ridge edges. Determines how broad the ridges appear. \\
\hline
{\em vmin} & Minimum value for the heightmap. Values below this threshold will be clamped to {\ttfamily vmin}. \\
\hline
{\em bbox} & Bounding box for the entire domain, defining the area covered by the heightmap. \\
\hline
{\em p\+\_\+noise\+\_\+x} & Pointer to an optional array for x-\/direction noise to apply to the heightmap. \\
\hline
{\em p\+\_\+noise\+\_\+y} & Pointer to an optional array for y-\/direction noise to apply to the heightmap. \\
\hline
{\em p\+\_\+stretching} & Pointer to an optional array for local wavenumber multipliers to stretch the ridges. \\
\hline
{\em bbox\+\_\+array} & Bounding box for the array domain, defining the spatial extent of the heightmap.\\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}

Generate a heightmap by stamping a kernel at predefined locations. 

This function creates a heightmap by stamping a specified kernel at given x, y, and z coordinates. The kernel can be scaled and manipulated based on the z-\/coordinates of the stamping points, and can be optionally flipped or rotated. The heightmap is generated by blending the results using the specified blending method. Randomization options are available for kernel manipulation.


\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}

\hline
{\em zr} & A vector of z-\/coordinates where the kernel is stamped. This affects the kernel radius and amplitude scaling. \\
\hline
{\em kernel} & The kernel to be stamped onto the heightmap. \\
\hline
{\em kernel\+\_\+ir} & The radius of the kernel in pixels. \\
\hline
{\em kernel\+\_\+scale\+\_\+radius} & Boolean flag to scale the kernel radius based on the z-\/coordinates. \\
\hline

\hline
{\em blend\+\_\+method} & The method used for blending multiple kernel stamps. Options may include additive, maximum, minimum, etc. \\
\hline
{\em seed} & Random seed number for kernel randomization. \\
\hline
{\em k\+\_\+smoothing} & Smoothing parameter for the heightmap (e.\+g., for smooth minimum or maximum blending). \\
\hline

\hline

\hline

\hline

Colorizes a slope height heatmap based on the gradient norms of a given array. 

This function computes a colorized heatmap using a two-\/dimensional histogram that considers the gradient norm of the input array. It normalizes both the input array values and their corresponding gradient norms, calculates a 2D histogram, and then applies a colormap to visualize the heatmap.


\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em array} & The input array for which the slope height heatmap is computed. This should be a 2D array representing height values. \\
\hline
{\em cmap} & An integer representing the colormap to be used for colorization. Colormap options depend on the colorization function used internally.\\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}
\begin{DoxyReturn}{Returns}
\doxylink{classhmap_1_1Tensor}{Tensor} representing the colorized heatmap, which visualizes the distribution of height values and their corresponding gradient norms.
\end{DoxyReturn}

\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item The function normalizes the height values and gradient norms independently using the minimum and maximum values.
\item A 2D histogram is constructed, where each bin corresponds to a pair of normalized height and gradient values.
\item The colormap is then applied to this histogram to produce a colorized output.
\end{DoxyItemize}

\begin{DoxyNote}{Note}
If the input array has a constant value (i.\+e., min == max), no normalization is applied, and the function may not produce meaningful results.
\end{DoxyNote}
\begin{DoxyWarning}{Warning}
Ensure that the input array is non-\/empty and has valid dimensions.
\end{DoxyWarning}

\doxysubsubsection{\texorpdfstring{curvature\_gaussian()}{curvature\_gaussian()}}
{\footnotesize\ttfamily \mbox{\hyperlink{classhmap_1_1Array}{Array}} hmap\+::curvature\+\_\+gaussian (\begin{DoxyParamCaption}\item[{const \mbox{\hyperlink{classhmap_1_1Array}{Array}} \&}]{z }\end{DoxyParamCaption})}



Calculates the Gaussian curvature of a heightmap, providing insights into the surface\textquotesingle{}s intrinsic curvature at each point. Gaussian curvature is a fundamental measure of surface curvature, indicating how the surface bends in multiple directions at each point. This metric is often used in geomorphology to understand landform shapes. Usage\+: Use this function to analyze the overall shape of terrain features, identifying whether regions are saddle-\/like, dome-\/like, or basin-\/like. Useful in studies related to tectonics, erosion patterns, and landform development. 


\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em z} & The input array representing the heightmap data (elevation values). \\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}
\begin{DoxyReturn}{Returns}
\doxylink{classhmap_1_1Array}{Array} An output array containing the Gaussian curvature values, with positive values indicating dome-\/like shapes and negative values indicating saddle shapes.
\end{DoxyReturn}

{\footnotesize\ttfamily \mbox{\hyperlink{classhmap_1_1Array}{Array}} hmap\+::curvature\+\_\+mean (\begin{DoxyParamCaption}\item[{const \mbox{\hyperlink{classhmap_1_1Array}{Array}} \&}]{z }\end{DoxyParamCaption})}



Computes the mean curvature of a heightmap, indicating the average curvature at each point on the surface. Mean curvature is another critical metric in geomorphology, representing the average bending of the surface. This measure is useful in understanding terrain smoothness and can help identify areas of potential erosion or deposition. Usage\+: Apply this function to detect areas prone to erosion or sediment deposition. Useful in landscape evolution models and in analyzing the stability of slopes. 


\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em z} & The input array representing the heightmap data (elevation values). \\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}
\begin{DoxyReturn}{Returns}
\doxylink{classhmap_1_1Array}{Array} An output array containing the mean curvature values, where positive values indicate convex regions and negative values indicate concave regions.
\end{DoxyReturn}

{\footnotesize\ttfamily \mbox{\hyperlink{classhmap_1_1Array}{Array}} hmap\+::curvature\+\_\+ring (\begin{DoxyParamCaption}\item[{const \mbox{\hyperlink{classhmap_1_1Array}{Array}} \&}]{z,  }\item[{int}]{ir }\end{DoxyParamCaption})}



Ring curvature is a second-\/order derivative of the elevation surface. It describes how the surface bends along a ring-\/like shape, often computed from the principal curvatures. Positive Values\+: Indicate convex surfaces where flow disperses (ridges, hilltops). Negative Values\+: Indicate concave surfaces where flow converges (valleys, depressions).

{\footnotesize\ttfamily \mbox{\hyperlink{classhmap_1_1Array}{Array}} hmap\+::curvature\+\_\+rotor (\begin{DoxyParamCaption}\item[{const \mbox{\hyperlink{classhmap_1_1Array}{Array}} \&}]{z,  }\item[{int}]{ir }\end{DoxyParamCaption})}



Rotor curvature, also called flow line curvature, describes how the curvature of a terrain surface influences the acceleration or deceleration of flow (e.\+g., water, debris, or air) along the direction of maximum slope. Positive values\+: Flow is decelerating (convex-\/up terrain, such as ridges or crests). Negative values\+: Flow is accelerating (concave-\/down terrain, such as valleys or channels). Zero values\+: Flow moves in a linear, constant-\/slope manner.

\doxysubsubsection{\texorpdfstring{shape\_index()}{shape\_index()}}
{\footnotesize\ttfamily \mbox{\hyperlink{classhmap_1_1Array}{Array}} hmap\+::shape\+\_\+index (\begin{DoxyParamCaption}\item[{const \mbox{\hyperlink{classhmap_1_1Array}{Array}} \&}]{z,  }\item[{int}]{ir }\end{DoxyParamCaption})}



Computes the Shape Index (SI) of the terrain, quantifying landform complexity based on curvature. The Shape Index is a metric used to describe the shape of landforms, particularly in digital elevation models (DEMs). It differentiates between convex (e.\+g., hilltops), concave (e.\+g., valleys), and flat surfaces. Usage\+: Use this function to classify terrain into different morphological types, which can be important in land use planning and environmental studies. Useful in landscape ecology and in understanding geomorphological processes. 


\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em z} & The input array representing the heightmap data (elevation values). \\
\hline
{\em ir} & The radius used for pre-\/filtering, which controls the scale of the analysis (in pixels). \\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}
\begin{DoxyReturn}{Returns}
\doxylink{classhmap_1_1Array}{Array} An output array containing Shape Index values, where values above 0.\+5 indicate convex shapes, and values below 0.\+5 indicate concave shapes.
\end{DoxyReturn}

\doxysubsubsection{\texorpdfstring{unsphericity()}{unsphericity()}}
{\footnotesize\ttfamily \mbox{\hyperlink{classhmap_1_1Array}{Array}} hmap\+::unsphericity (\begin{DoxyParamCaption}\item[{const \mbox{\hyperlink{classhmap_1_1Array}{Array}} \&}]{z,  }\item[{int}]{ir }\end{DoxyParamCaption})}



Calculates the unsphericity of a surface, indicating how much the terrain deviates from a perfect spherical shape. Unsphericity is a measure used to understand the degree of asymmetry in terrain surfaces. It quantifies how much a surface deviates from being perfectly spherical or symmetrical, which can be critical in various geomorphological analyses. Usage\+: Use this function to identify areas of terrain that significantly deviate from a spherical shape, which may indicate unique geological formations or erosion patterns. Helpful in identifying and analyzing landforms that are not perfectly round or symmetrical, such as irregular hills or basins. 


\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em z} & The input array representing the heightmap data (elevation values). \\
\hline
{\em ir} & The radius used for pre-\/filtering, controlling the scale of analysis (in pixels). \\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}
\begin{DoxyReturn}{Returns}
\doxylink{classhmap_1_1Array}{Array} An output array containing unsphericity values, where values greater than 0.\+5 indicate convex regions (e.\+g., peaks) and values less than 0.\+5 indicate concave regions (e.\+g., valleys).
\end{DoxyReturn}

\DoxyCodeLine{\textcolor{preprocessor}{\#include\ "{}\mbox{\hyperlink{highmap_8hpp}{highmap.hpp}}"{}}}

Apply hydraulic erosion using a particle based procedure, using a pyramid decomposition to allow a multiscale approach. 


\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}

\hline
{\em particle\+\_\+density} & Particles density (with respect to the number of cells of the input array). \\

\hline

\hline

\hline

\hline

\hline

\hline
{\em c\+\_\+erosion} & Erosion coefficient. \\
\hline
{\em drag\+\_\+rate} & Drag rate. \\
\hline

\hline

Generates a procedurally eroded terrain using hydraulic erosion and ridge generation techniques. 

This function applies a combination of hydraulic erosion and ridge formation to modify a heightmap, leveraging parameters such as erosion profiles, ridge scaling, and noise characteristics. It also supports custom or default masks to influence the erosion process.


\begin{DoxyParams}[1]{Parameters}
\mbox{\texttt{ out}}  & {\em z} & The heightmap to be modified, represented as a 2D array. \\
\hline
\mbox{\texttt{ in}}  & {\em seed} & Random seed for procedural generation. \\
\hline
\mbox{\texttt{ in}}  & {\em ridge\+\_\+wavelength} & Wavelength of the ridge structures in the heightmap. \\
\hline
\mbox{\texttt{ in}}  & {\em ridge\+\_\+scaling} & Scaling factor for the ridge height. \\
\hline
\mbox{\texttt{ in}}  & {\em erosion\+\_\+profile} & The profile that defines the erosion curve behavior. \\
\hline
\mbox{\texttt{ in}}  & {\em delta} & Parameter controlling the erosion intensity. \\
\hline
\mbox{\texttt{ in}}  & {\em noise\+\_\+ratio} & Ratio of noise added to the ridge crest lines. \\
\hline
\mbox{\texttt{ in}}  & {\em prefilter\+\_\+ir} & Kernel radius for pre-\/smoothing the heightmap. If negative, a default value is computed. \\
\hline
\mbox{\texttt{ in}}  & {\em density\+\_\+factor} & Factor influencing the density of the ridges. \\
\hline
\mbox{\texttt{ in}}  & {\em kernel\+\_\+width\+\_\+ratio} & Ratio defining the width of the ridge generation kernel. \\
\hline
\mbox{\texttt{ in}}  & {\em phase\+\_\+smoothing} & Smoothing factor for the phase field used in ridge generation. \\
\hline
\mbox{\texttt{ in}}  & {\em use\+\_\+default\+\_\+mask} & Whether to use a default mask for erosion if no mask is provided. \\
\hline
\mbox{\texttt{ in}}  & {\em talus\+\_\+mask} & Threshold for default mask slope to identify regions prone to erosion. \\
\hline
\mbox{\texttt{ in}}  & {\em p\+\_\+mask} & Optional pointer to a custom mask array to influence the erosion process. \\
\hline
\mbox{\texttt{ out}}  & {\em p\+\_\+ridge\+\_\+mask} & Optional pointer to store the ridge mask resulting from the operation. \\
\hline
\mbox{\texttt{ in}}  & {\em vmin} & Minimum elevation value. If set to a sentinel value (vmax \texorpdfstring{$<$}{<} vmin), it is calculated from the heightmap. \\
\hline
\mbox{\texttt{ in}}  & {\em vmax} & Maximum elevation value. If set to a sentinel value (vmax \texorpdfstring{$<$}{<} vmin), it is calculated from the heightmap.\\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}

{\footnotesize\ttfamily void hmap\+::hydraulic\+\_\+stream\+\_\+upscale\+\_\+amplification (\begin{DoxyParamCaption}\item[{\mbox{\hyperlink{classhmap_1_1Array}{Array}} \&}]{z,  }\item[{float}]{c\+\_\+erosion,  }\item[{float}]{talus\+\_\+ref,  }\item[{int}]{upscaling\+\_\+levels = {\ttfamily 1},  }\item[{float}]{persistence = {\ttfamily 1.\mbox{\hyperlink{distance__transform_8cpp_abcb9259cf91bfd25e92a72cdf18c285e}{f}}},  }\item[{int}]{ir = {\ttfamily 1},  }\item[{float}]{clipping\+\_\+ratio = {\ttfamily 10.\mbox{\hyperlink{distance__transform_8cpp_abcb9259cf91bfd25e92a72cdf18c285e}{f}}} }\end{DoxyParamCaption})}



Applies hydraulic erosion with upscaling amplification. 

This function progressively upscales the input array {\ttfamily z} by powers of 2 and applies hydraulic erosion based on flow accumulation at each level of upscaling. After all upscaling levels are processed, the array is resampled back to its original resolution using bilinear interpolation.


\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em z} & Input array representing elevation data. \\
\hline
{\em c\+\_\+erosion} & Erosion coefficient. \\
\hline
{\em talus\+\_\+ref} & Reference talus used to locally define the flow-\/partition exponent. Smaller values lead to thinner flow streams. \\
\hline
{\em upscaling\+\_\+levels} & Number of upscaling levels to apply. The function will resample the array at each level. \\
\hline
{\em persistence} & A scaling factor applied at each level to adjust the impact of the unary operation. Higher persistence values will amplify the effects at each level. \\
\hline
{\em ir} & Kernel radius. If {\ttfamily ir \texorpdfstring{$>$}{>} 1}, a cone kernel is used to carve channel flow erosion. \\
\hline
{\em clipping\+\_\+ratio} & Flow accumulation clipping ratio.\\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}
\begin{DoxyNote}{Note}
The function first applies upscaling using bicubic resampling, performs hydraulic erosion at each level, and finally resamples the array back to its initial resolution using bilinear interpolation.
\end{DoxyNote}

Similar to the overloaded version, this function progressively upscales the input array {\ttfamily z} and applies hydraulic erosion. Additionally, an intensity mask {\ttfamily p\+\_\+mask} is applied as a post-\/processing step.

\hline

\hline
{\em persistence} & A scaling factor applied at each level to adjust the impact of the unary operation. Higher persistence values will amplify the effects at each level. \\
\hline
{\em ir} & Kernel radius. If {\ttfamily ir \texorpdfstring{$>$}{>} 1}, a cone kernel is used to carve channel flow erosion. \\
\hline
{\em clipping\+\_\+ratio} & Flow accumulation clipping ratio.\\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}

\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}

\hline

\hline
{\em gradient\+\_\+scaling\+\_\+ratio} & Scaling factor for gradient-\/based erosion. \\
\hline

\hline

\hline

Apply thermal weathering erosion. 

Based on averaging over first neighbors, see {\bfseries [Olsen2004]}. Refer to {\bfseries [Musgrave1989]} for the original formulation.

Thermal erosion refers to the process in which surface sediment weakens due to temperature and detaches, falling down the slopes of the terrain until a resting place is reached, where smooth plateaus tend to form {\bfseries [Musgrave1989]}.

Applies the thermal erosion process to an array of elevation values. 

This function simulates thermal erosion by modifying the elevation values in the array {\ttfamily z}. It compares the slope between each cell and its neighbors with a specified threshold ({\ttfamily talus}). If the slope exceeds the threshold, material is considered to move from higher to lower cells, resulting in a smoother terrain.


\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em z} & Reference to the array of elevation values that will be modified. \\
\hline
{\em talus} & \doxylink{classhmap_1_1Array}{Array} of threshold slope values for each cell, representing stability criteria. \\
\hline
{\em iterations} & Number of erosion iterations to apply. \\
\hline
{\em intensity} & Intensity factor controlling the amount of change per iteration.\\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}

Exports a heightmap to various 3D file formats. 

This function exports the input heightmap array as a 3D asset in the specified format. The export can include different mesh types, elevation scaling, and optional texture and normal maps. The function supports optimized Delaunay triangulation for mesh generation, with a configurable maximum error.


\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}

\hline

\hline
{\em export\+\_\+format} & The format in which to export the asset (see {\ttfamily \doxylink{namespacehmap_ac3d35efc6e5b596f508e2b17a5aa871b}{Asset\+Export\+Format}}). \\
\hline
{\em elevation\+\_\+scaling} & A scaling factor applied to the elevation values of the heightmap. Default is 0.\+2f. \\
\hline
{\em texture\+\_\+fname} & The name of the texture file to be applied to the asset (optional). \\
\hline
{\em normal\+\_\+map\+\_\+fname} & The name of the normal map file to be applied to the asset (optional). \\
\hline

Exports a 2D array as a cubemap texture with continuity enforcement and overlapping regions. 

This function generates a cubemap texture from the input array {\ttfamily z}, resamples the data to fit the cubemap resolution with optional overlapping regions, and ensures seamless transitions between the six faces of the cubemap. The cubemap can either be saved as a single texture or split into individual face textures.


\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em fname} & Output file name or base name for the cubemap files. \\
\hline
{\em z} & Input 2D array representing the data to be converted into a cubemap. \\
\hline
{\em cubemap\+\_\+resolution} & Resolution (width and height) of each individual face of the cubemap. \\
\hline
{\em overlap} & Fraction (0 to 1) of overlap between adjacent faces to ensure smooth transitions. \\
\hline
{\em ir} & Radius parameter for smoothing at triple corners. \\
\hline
{\em cmap} & Colormap to be applied when exporting the textures. \\
\hline
{\em splitted} & If true, exports each face of the cubemap as a separate image; otherwise, exports the entire cubemap as a single texture. \\
\hline
{\em p\+\_\+cubemap} & Pointer to an optional output array where the final cubemap data will be stored.\\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}
The generated cubemap maintains continuity between faces, adjusting values at overlapping regions and corners using smooth transitions. If the {\ttfamily splitted} flag is set, six individual PNG images are generated for the cubemap faces with appropriate suffixes appended to the base name. Otherwise, the entire cubemap is exported as a single texture file.

Exports a 2D array as a set of grayscale PNG image tiles.

\hline

Performs k-\/means clustering on three input arrays, providing more detailed cluster analysis by considering an additional dimension. 

This version of k-\/means clustering includes a third array, enabling more complex clustering based on three terrain attributes or environmental variables.

{\bfseries{Usage}}
\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item Apply this function to analyze the relationships between three different terrain attributes, revealing complex patterns.
\item Useful in multi-\/dimensional environmental modeling and resource management.
\end{DoxyItemize}


\begin{DoxyParams}[1]{Parameters}
\mbox{\texttt{ in}}  & {\em array1} & The first input array for clustering. \\
\hline
\mbox{\texttt{ in}}  & {\em array2} & The second input array for clustering. \\
\hline
\mbox{\texttt{ in}}  & {\em array3} & The third input array for clustering. \\
\hline
\mbox{\texttt{ in}}  & {\em nclusters} & The number of clusters (k) to be formed. \\
\hline
\mbox{\texttt{ out}}  & {\em p\+\_\+scoring} & (optional) A pointer to a vector of arrays where the clustering scores will be stored. Pass nullptr if scoring is not required. \\
\hline
\mbox{\texttt{ out}}  & {\em p\+\_\+aggregate\+\_\+scoring} & (optional) A pointer to an array where the aggregate score across all clusters will be stored. Pass nullptr if not required. \\
\hline
\mbox{\texttt{ in}}  & {\em weights} & A vector of three floats representing the weight given to {\ttfamily array1}, {\ttfamily array2}, and {\ttfamily array3}. The default weights are \{1.\+f, 1.\+f, 1.\+f\}. \\
\hline
\mbox{\texttt{ in}}  & {\em seed} & A seed value for random number generation, ensuring reproducibility of the clustering results. The default value is 1. \\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}

\doxylink{classhmap_1_1Array}{Array} An array representing the clustered data, with each pixel assigned to a cluster.

\doxysubsubsection{\texorpdfstring{local\_median\_deviation()}{local\_median\_deviation()}}
{\footnotesize\ttfamily \mbox{\hyperlink{classhmap_1_1Array}{Array}} hmap\+::local\+\_\+median\+\_\+deviation (\begin{DoxyParamCaption}\item[{const \mbox{\hyperlink{classhmap_1_1Array}{Array}} \&}]{array,  }\item[{int}]{ir }\end{DoxyParamCaption})}



Computes the local median deviation of a 2D array. 

This function calculates the absolute difference between the local mean and a pseudo-\/local median of each element in the input array. The local neighborhood is defined by a square window with radius {\ttfamily ir}.


\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em array} & The input 2D array of values (e.\+g., a heightmap). \\
\hline
{\em ir} & The radius of the square neighborhood window used for computing local statistics. The window size is (2\texorpdfstring{$\ast$}{*}ir + 1) x (2\texorpdfstring{$\ast$}{*}ir + 1).\\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}
\begin{DoxyReturn}{Returns}
A new array of the same size as {\ttfamily array}, where each element represents the absolute deviation between the local mean and pseudo-\/local median in its neighborhood.
\end{DoxyReturn}
\begin{DoxyNote}{Note}
The function uses a pseudo-\/median approximation. For exact median computation, replace the {\ttfamily \doxylink{namespacehmap_a14eb6b7d304484c8cbb231b672851491}{median\+\_\+pseudo()}} call with a proper median filter implementation.
\end{DoxyNote}

Applies diffusion retargeting by detecting local maxima and adjusting based on the difference between two arrays. 

This function identifies points of interest in the {\ttfamily array\+\_\+before} (local maxima in a 3x3 neighborhood), computes the difference between the corresponding points in {\ttfamily array\+\_\+before} and {\ttfamily array\+\_\+after}, and stores these differences in a delta array. It then applies smoothing to the delta values, remaps them within the original min-\/max range, and returns the corrected array by adding the adjusted delta to {\ttfamily array\+\_\+after}.


\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em array\+\_\+before} & The original 2D array used to detect local maxima for retargeting. \\
\hline
{\em array\+\_\+after} & The 2D array representing the state after the diffusion process. \\
\hline
{\em ir} & The smoothing radius used in the smoothing step ({\ttfamily smooth\+\_\+cpulse}).\\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}
\begin{DoxyReturn}{Returns}
A new 2D array where the delta between the two input arrays has been smoothed and applied as a correction to {\ttfamily array\+\_\+after}.
\end{DoxyReturn}

Applies a directional blur to a 2D array based on a spatially varying angle field. 

This function performs an anisotropic blur on the input {\ttfamily array}, using the {\ttfamily angle} array to determine the direction of blur at each pixel. The blur is computed by sampling values along a line in the specified direction (per-\/pixel), using linear interpolation through an {\ttfamily \doxylink{classhmap_1_1ArrayFunction}{Array\+Function}}. The amount of blur is controlled by parameters for intensity, stretching, and spread.

For each pixel, the function samples values along the blur direction determined by {\ttfamily angle(i, j)} (in degrees), applies a smooth weight profile ({\ttfamily smoothstep3}) over a range of {\ttfamily 2 \texorpdfstring{$\ast$}{*} ir -\/ 1} steps, and accumulates the weighted values. The output is then normalized by the total weight sum.


\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em array} & The input/output 2D array to be blurred (modified in-\/place). \\
\hline
{\em ir} & Blur radius\+: the number of samples on each side of the center (total samples = 2 \texorpdfstring{$\ast$}{*} ir -\/ 1). \\
\hline
{\em angle} & A 2D array of the same shape as {\ttfamily array} giving blur direction (in degrees) at each pixel. 0° points to the right (positive X), 90° points upward (positive Y). \\
\hline
{\em intensity} & The overall weight of the blur effect (scales the weight profile). \\
\hline
{\em stretch} & A scaling factor applied to the sampling step along the blur direction. Higher values stretch the blur further along the direction vector. \\
\hline
{\em spread} & Maximum normalized distance at which blur weights are applied (used in smoothstep weight profile).\\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}
\begin{DoxyNote}{Note}
Uses linear interpolation through an {\ttfamily \doxylink{classhmap_1_1ArrayFunction}{Array\+Function}}, and wraps coordinates using clamping (not periodic).
\end{DoxyNote}

This function approximates the effect of a median filter by computing the local minimum, maximum, and mean values within a square neighborhood of radius {\ttfamily ir}, and averaging the results\+:

\[
\text{pseudo\_median}(x, y) = \frac{\text{min} + \text{max} + \text{mean}}{3}
\]

This method is computationally cheaper than a true median filter and can approximate its noise-\/reduction and edge-\/preserving properties to some extent.


\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em array} & Input array (e.\+g., image or 2D signal). \\
\hline
{\em ir} & Radius of the square neighborhood (kernel size will be $2
              \cdot ir + 1$). \\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}
\begin{DoxyReturn}{Returns}
An \doxylink{classhmap_1_1Array}{Array} containing the pseudo-\/median filtered output.
\end{DoxyReturn}
\begin{DoxyNote}{Note}
This method works best on images with impulsive noise (e.\+g., salt-\/and-\/pepper), but is only an approximation and may behave differently from a true median filter on complex structures or edges.
\end{DoxyNote}

\doxysubsubsection{\texorpdfstring{recast\_canyon()}{recast\_canyon()}\hspace{0.1cm}{\footnotesize\ttfamily [1/4]}}
{\footnotesize\ttfamily void hmap\+::recast\+\_\+canyon (\begin{DoxyParamCaption}\item[{\mbox{\hyperlink{classhmap_1_1Array}{Array}} \&}]{array,  }\item[{const \mbox{\hyperlink{classhmap_1_1Array}{Array}} \&}]{vcut,  }\item[{float}]{gamma = {\ttfamily 4.\mbox{\hyperlink{distance__transform_8cpp_abcb9259cf91bfd25e92a72cdf18c285e}{f}}} }\end{DoxyParamCaption})}



Transform heightmap to give a "{}canyon"{} like appearance. 

This function modifies the heightmap to create a "{}canyon"{} effect. The transformation is based on a canyon top elevation ({\ttfamily vcut}). The effect can be adjusted with a gamma factor to control the intensity of the canyon effect. Optional parameters include a filter mask for selective application and a noise array for additional variation.


\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em array} & Input array representing the heightmap to be transformed. \\
\hline
{\em vcut} & Canyon top elevation. This value defines the threshold for canyon formation. \\
\hline
{\em gamma} & Gamma factor (\texorpdfstring{$>$}{>} 0) that adjusts the intensity of the canyon effect. A higher value increases the effect. The default value is 4.\+0. \\
\hline
{\em p\+\_\+mask} & Optional filter mask, with values expected in the range \mbox{[}0, 1\mbox{]}. The mask specifies which parts of the heightmap are affected by the transformation. \\
\hline
{\em p\+\_\+noise} & Optional noise array used to introduce variation in the canyon effect. If not provided, no additional noise is applied.\\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}

{\footnotesize\ttfamily void hmap\+::recast\+\_\+cliff (\begin{DoxyParamCaption}\item[{\mbox{\hyperlink{classhmap_1_1Array}{Array}} \&}]{array,  }\item[{float}]{talus,  }\item[{int}]{ir,  }\item[{float}]{amplitude,  }\item[{float}]{gain = {\ttfamily 2.\mbox{\hyperlink{distance__transform_8cpp_abcb9259cf91bfd25e92a72cdf18c285e}{f}}} }\end{DoxyParamCaption})}



Transform heightmap to add cliffs where gradients are steep enough. 

This function modifies the heightmap to introduce cliffs based on a reference talus angle. Cliffs are added where the gradient exceeds the specified talus angle. The amplitude of the cliffs and the gain factor for steepness are adjustable. Additionally, a filter mask can be applied to control which parts of the heightmap are affected.


\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em array} & Input array representing the heightmap to be modified. \\
\hline
{\em talus} & Reference talus angle. This angle determines the threshold above which cliffs are formed. \\
\hline
{\em ir} & Filter radius used to smooth the heightmap before applying the cliff effect. \\
\hline
{\em amplitude} & Amplitude of the cliffs. This value controls the height of the cliffs. \\
\hline
{\em gain} & Gain factor for the gain filter, influencing the steepness of the cliffs. Higher values result in steeper cliffs. The default value is 2.\+0. \\
\hline
{\em p\+\_\+mask} & Optional filter mask, with values expected in the range \mbox{[}0, 1\mbox{]}. The mask specifies which parts of the heightmap are affected by the cliff transformation.\\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}

{\footnotesize\ttfamily void hmap\+::recast\+\_\+cliff\+\_\+directional (\begin{DoxyParamCaption}\item[{\mbox{\hyperlink{classhmap_1_1Array}{Array}} \&}]{array,  }\item[{float}]{talus,  }\item[{int}]{ir,  }\item[{float}]{amplitude,  }\item[{float}]{angle,  }\item[{float}]{gain = {\ttfamily 2.\mbox{\hyperlink{distance__transform_8cpp_abcb9259cf91bfd25e92a72cdf18c285e}{f}}} }\end{DoxyParamCaption})}



Transform heightmap to add directional cliffs where gradients are steep enough. 

This function modifies the heightmap to introduce cliffs in a specific direction, based on a reference talus angle. The cliffs are added where the gradient exceeds the specified talus angle, with the direction of the cliffs controlled by the specified angle. The amplitude of the cliffs and the gain factor for steepness are also adjustable. A filter mask can be used to specify which parts of the heightmap are affected.


\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em array} & Input array representing the heightmap to be modified. \\
\hline
{\em talus} & Reference talus angle. This angle determines the threshold above which cliffs are formed. \\
\hline
{\em ir} & Filter radius used to smooth the heightmap before applying the cliff effect. \\
\hline
{\em amplitude} & Amplitude of the cliffs. This value controls the height of the cliffs. \\
\hline
{\em angle} & Angle (in degrees) determining the direction of the cliffs. \\
\hline
{\em gain} & Gain factor for the gain filter, influencing the steepness of the cliffs. Higher values result in steeper cliffs. The default value is 2.\+0. \\
\hline
{\em p\+\_\+mask} & Optional filter mask, with values expected in the range \mbox{[}0, 1\mbox{]}. The mask specifies which parts of the heightmap are affected by the cliff transformation.\\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}

Applies an escarpment effect to the given 2D array, modifying its values based on cumulative displacement with optional directional and transpositional transformations. 

This function calculates cumulative displacement along the x-\/axis based on relative elevation differences between adjacent cells. The displacement is scaled and optionally reversed, then used to apply a warping effect to the array, simulating an escarpment feature. An optional global scaling factor can further adjust the displacement effect intensity.


\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em array} & Reference to the 2D array where the escarpment effect will be applied. \\
\hline
{\em ir} & Radius for the smoothing kernel used on the displacement, controlling the smoothness of the effect. Larger values result in smoother transitions. \\
\hline
{\em ratio} & The ratio influencing displacement; values \texorpdfstring{$>$}{>} 1.\+0 increase displacement sensitivity to height differences. \\
\hline
{\em scale} & The scaling factor for the cumulative displacement, affecting the intensity of the effect. \\
\hline
{\em reverse} & If true, reverses the direction of the displacement effect. \\
\hline
{\em transpose\+\_\+effect} & If true, transposes the array before and after applying the effect. \\
\hline
{\em global\+\_\+scaling} & An additional scaling factor for the displacement; if set to 0, a default value is computed based on the array\textquotesingle{}s range and size. Higher values increase the overall effect.\\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}

Applies an escarpment effect to the given 2D array, with an optional mask to blend the effect. 

This overload allows for a blending mask that controls the intensity of the escarpment effect at each point in the array. The mask values range between 0 and 1, where values closer to 1 fully apply the effect, and values closer to 0 reduce it. An optional global scaling factor can further adjust the displacement effect intensity.


\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em array} & Reference to the 2D array where the escarpment effect will be applied. \\
\hline
{\em p\+\_\+mask} & Pointer to an optional mask array for blending the effect, where values range from 0 to 1. A nullptr applies the effect fully without blending. \\
\hline
{\em ir} & Radius for the smoothing kernel used on the displacement, controlling the smoothness of the effect. Larger values result in smoother transitions. \\
\hline
{\em ratio} & The ratio influencing displacement; values \texorpdfstring{$>$}{>} 1.\+0 increase displacement sensitivity to height differences. \\
\hline
{\em scale} & The scaling factor for the cumulative displacement, affecting the intensity of the effect. \\
\hline
{\em reverse} & If true, reverses the direction of the displacement effect. \\
\hline
{\em transpose\+\_\+effect} & If true, transposes the array before and after applying the effect. \\
\hline
{\em global\+\_\+scaling} & An additional scaling factor for the displacement; if set to 0, a default value is computed based on the array\textquotesingle{}s range and size. Higher values increase the overall effect.\\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}

\doxysubsubsection{\texorpdfstring{recast\_peak()}{recast\_peak()}\hspace{0.1cm}{\footnotesize\ttfamily [1/2]}}
{\footnotesize\ttfamily void hmap\+::recast\+\_\+peak (\begin{DoxyParamCaption}\item[{\mbox{\hyperlink{classhmap_1_1Array}{Array}} \&}]{array,  }\item[{int}]{ir,  }\item[{float}]{gamma = {\ttfamily 2.\mbox{\hyperlink{distance__transform_8cpp_abcb9259cf91bfd25e92a72cdf18c285e}{f}}},  }\item[{float}]{k = {\ttfamily 0.1\mbox{\hyperlink{distance__transform_8cpp_abcb9259cf91bfd25e92a72cdf18c285e}{f}}} }\end{DoxyParamCaption})}



Transform heightmap to give a "{}peak"{} like appearance. 

This function modifies the heightmap to create a "{}peak"{} effect, where the elevations are adjusted to emphasize peak-\/like features. The transformation is applied based on a filter radius ({\ttfamily ir}) and involves gamma correction and smoothing parameters. The effect can be selectively applied using a filter mask.

\begin{DoxyWarning}{Warning}
\doxylink{classhmap_1_1Array}{Array} values are expected to be in the range \mbox{[}0, 1\mbox{]}.
\end{DoxyWarning}

\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em array} & Input array representing the heightmap to be transformed. \\
\hline
{\em ir} & Filter radius used to smooth the heightmap before applying the peak effect. \\
\hline
{\em gamma} & Gamma factor (\texorpdfstring{$>$}{>} 0) that adjusts the intensity of the peak effect. A higher value increases the effect. The default value is 2.\+0. For details on gamma correction, see {\ttfamily \doxylink{namespacehmap_aba3674787d520af15267ee7d1e46d220}{gamma\+\_\+correction}}. \\
\hline
{\em k} & Smoothing parameter (\texorpdfstring{$>$}{>} 0) that controls the degree of smoothing applied during the transformation. Higher values result in more smoothing. The default value is 0.\+1. \\
\hline
{\em p\+\_\+mask} & Optional filter mask, with values expected in the range \mbox{[}0, 1\mbox{]}. The mask specifies which parts of the heightmap are affected by the peak transformation.\\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}

Transform heightmap by adding "{}rock-\/like"{} features at higher slopes. 

This function modifies the heightmap to introduce rock-\/like features, particularly at locations with higher slopes. The transformation is controlled by parameters defining talus limit, filter radius, amplitude, and noise characteristics. The rock features are generated using a specified random seed and can be customized with optional noise and gamma correction. A filter mask can be applied to control which parts of the heightmap are affected.


\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em array} & Input array representing the heightmap to be transformed. \\
\hline
{\em talus} & Talus limit that determines the threshold above which rock-\/like features are introduced based on slope steepness. \\
\hline
{\em ir} & Filter radius used to smooth the heightmap and define the area of influence for adding rock features. \\
\hline
{\em amplitude} & Amplitude of the rock features. This value controls the intensity of the rock-\/like appearance. \\
\hline
{\em seed} & Random number seed used to generate noise patterns for the rock features. Different seeds produce different rock patterns. \\
\hline
{\em kw} & Noise wavenumber with respect to a unit domain, influencing the frequency of rock features. Higher values result in more detailed rock textures. \\
\hline
{\em gamma} & Gamma correction coefficient applied to the rock features. This parameter adjusts the contrast of the rock features. The default value is 0.\+5. \\
\hline
{\em p\+\_\+noise} & Optional reference to an input noise array used for generating rock features. If provided, it overrides the default noise generator. \\
\hline
{\em p\+\_\+mask} & Optional filter mask, with values expected in the range \mbox{[}0, 1\mbox{]}. The mask specifies which parts of the heightmap are affected by the rock feature transformation. \\
\hline
{\em bbox} & Bounding box defining the region of interest within the heightmap. This parameter specifies the coordinates of the bounding box in the format \{xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax\}. The default bounding box covers the entire domain.\\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}

Transform heightmap to give a "{}cliff"{} like appearance. 

This function modifies the heightmap to create a "{}cliff"{} effect by folding the elevations around a reference height ({\ttfamily vref}). The transformation is influenced by a smoothing coefficient ({\ttfamily k}) and can be selectively applied using a filter mask.


\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em array} & Input array representing the heightmap to be transformed. \\
\hline
{\em vref} & Reference elevation where the heightmap is folded to create the cliff-\/like appearance. Elevations near this value will be prominently altered. \\
\hline
{\em k} & Smoothing coefficient that controls the degree of smoothing applied during the transformation. A higher value results in smoother cliffs. The default value is not specified in this function; it must be provided by the user. \\
\hline
{\em p\+\_\+mask} & Optional filter mask, with values expected in the range \mbox{[}0, 1\mbox{]}. The mask specifies which parts of the heightmap are affected by the cliff transformation. If not provided, the transformation is applied to the entire heightmap.\\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}

Apply a curve adjustment filter to the array. 

This function applies a curve adjustment to the heightmap by mapping input values to output values according to a given correction curve. The curve is monotonically interpolated, and any values outside the defined input range are clipped. The filter can be selectively applied using a mask.


\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em array} & Input array representing the heightmap to be adjusted. \\
\hline
{\em t} & Vector of input values for the correction curve. These values define the x-\/coordinates (input values) of the curve. \\
\hline
{\em v} & Vector of output values for the correction curve. These values define the y-\/coordinates (output values) of the curve corresponding to the input values in {\ttfamily t}. \\
\hline
{\em p\+\_\+mask} & Optional filter mask, with values expected in the range \mbox{[}0, 1\mbox{]}. The mask specifies which parts of the heightmap are affected by the curve adjustment. If not provided, the curve adjustment is applied to the entire heightmap.\\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}

Apply a curve adjustment filter using an nth-\/order smoothstep curve. 

This function applies a curve adjustment to the heightmap using a smoothstep function of order {\ttfamily n}. The smoothstep function provides a smooth transition between 0 and 1, where {\ttfamily n} determines the smoothness of the transition. Apply directional shrinking, or "{}deflating"{}, to emphasize the ridges in the terrain. 

This function applies a directional shrinking filter to the input array, enhancing the ridges by shrinking or deflating the terrain features with respect to a specified direction. Parameters include filter radius {\ttfamily ir}, direction angle, aspect ratio, and anisotropy to control the shape and orientation of the filter. An optional filter mask can be used for selective application.

\hline

\hline

\hline

Apply filtering to the array using convolution with a cubic pulse kernel. 

This function performs convolution on the input array using a cubic pulse kernel. It serves as an alternative to Gaussian smoothing, offering a more compact support with potentially faster computations. For direct comparison with Gaussian smoothing, the pulse radius {\ttfamily ir} should be set to twice the desired Gaussian half-\/width.


\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}

\hline
{\em ir} & Pulse radius, where the half-\/width of the cubic pulse kernel is half of this value. \\
\hline

\hline
\end{DoxyParams}

Applies a terrace effect to the values in an array. 

This function adjusts the values in the {\ttfamily array} by applying a terrace or stepped effect, often used for terrain generation or other natural-\/looking height variations. The terrace effect is controlled by several parameters such as the number of levels, gain, noise ratio, and optional min/max range. The noise is applied to levels for added randomness, and a gain function is applied to smooth the transitions.


\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}

\hline
{\em gain} & Gain factor for controlling the sharpness of the terrace levels, in \mbox{[}0, 1\mbox{]}. \\
\hline
{\em noise\+\_\+ratio} & Ratio of noise applied to each terrace level, except the first and last. \\
\hline
{\em p\+\_\+noise} & Optional noise array to introduce additional variation per element. \\
\hline
{\em vmin} & Minimum value for terracing; if less than {\ttfamily vmax}, will be auto-\/determined. \\
\hline

\hline
\end{DoxyParams}

Applies a terrace effect to an array with optional masking. 

This overloaded version of the terrace function modifies {\ttfamily array} based on the terrace levels, gain, noise ratio, and an optional mask array. If a mask is provided, the terrace effect is applied conditionally based on the mask values.


\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em array} & The array of values to modify with the terrace effect. \\
\hline
{\em seed} & Seed value for random number generation. \\
\hline

\hline

\hline
{\em p\+\_\+noise} & Optional noise array to introduce additional variation per element. \\
\hline
{\em vmin} & Minimum value for terracing; if less than {\ttfamily vmax}, will be auto-\/determined. \\
\hline
{\em vmax} & Maximum value for terracing; if less than {\ttfamily vmin}, will be auto-\/determined.\\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}

\begin{DoxyItemize}

Apply wrinkle effect to the array, creating wrinkled or bumpy features. 

This function adds wrinkle-\/like features to the input array. The {\ttfamily wrinkle\+\_\+amplitude} controls the intensity of the wrinkling effect, while other parameters such as {\ttfamily displacement\+\_\+amplitude}, {\ttfamily ir}, {\ttfamily kw}, {\ttfamily seed}, {\ttfamily octaves}, and {\ttfamily weight} control various aspects of the underlying noise and wrinkle generation.


\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em array} & Input array to which wrinkles will be applied. \\
\hline
{\em wrinkle\+\_\+amplitude} & Amplitude of the wrinkle effect. \\
\hline
{\em p\+\_\+mask} & Optional filter mask, expected in the range \mbox{[}0, 1\mbox{]}. If provided, the wrinkle effect is applied according to this mask. If not provided, the entire array is processed. \\
\hline
{\em wrinkle\+\_\+angle} & Overall rotation angle (in degree). \\
\hline
{\em displacement\+\_\+amplitude} & Drives the displacement of the wrinkles. \\
\hline
{\em ir} & Smooth filter radius applied during wrinkle generation. \\
\hline
{\em kw} & Underlying primitive wavenumber, affecting the frequency of wrinkles. \\
\hline
{\em seed} & Random seed number for generating underlying primitive noise. \\
\hline
{\em octaves} & Number of octaves used in the underlying primitive noise. \\
\hline
{\em weight} & Weight of the underlying primitive noise. \\
\hline
{\em bbox} & Bounding box for the generated wrinkles, default is \{0.\+f, 1.\+f, 0.\+f, 1.\+f\}.\\
\hline

Dig a path on a heightmap. 

This function modifies a heightmap array by "{}digging"{} a path into it based on the provided path. The path is represented by a {\ttfamily \doxylink{classhmap_1_1Path}{Path}} object, and the function adjusts the height values in the {\ttfamily z} array to create the appearance of a dug path. The width, border decay, and flattening radius parameters control the characteristics of the dig. Optionally, the path can be forced to have a monotonically decreasing elevation.

\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}

{\em path} & The path to be dug into the heightmap, with coordinates with respect to a unit-\/square. The path will be processed to create the dig effect. \\
\hline
{\em width} & Radius of the path width in pixels. This determines how wide the dug path will be. \\

\hline
{\em force\+\_\+downhill} & If {\ttfamily true}, the path\textquotesingle{}s elevation will be forced to decrease monotonically, creating a downhill effect. \\
\hline
{\em bbox} & Bounding box specifying the region of the heightmap to consider for the digging operation. It defines the area where the path is applied. \\

Modifies the elevation array to carve a river along a specified path. 

This function adjusts the elevation values in the input array {\ttfamily z} to simulate a river along the provided {\ttfamily path}. It incorporates parameters for riverbed and riverbank slopes, noise effects, and merging behavior to create a realistic river profile.


\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em z} & The input 2D array representing the elevation map. This array will be modified in place. \\
\hline
{\em path} & The path along which the river is to be carved, represented as a sequence of points, with coordinates with respect to a unit-\/square. \\
\hline
{\em riverbank\+\_\+talus} & The slope of the riverbank, controlling how steep the river\textquotesingle{}s edges are. \\
\hline
{\em merging\+\_\+ir} & The merging radius, specifying how far the effects of multiple rivers combine. \\
\hline
{\em riverbed\+\_\+talus} & The slope of the riverbed, controlling how steep the riverbed is (default\+: 0.\+0). \\
\hline
{\em noise\+\_\+ratio} & The proportion of random noise applied to the river\textquotesingle{}s shape for realism (default\+: 0.\+9). \\
\hline
{\em seed} & The seed for the random noise generator, ensuring reproducibility (default\+: 0).\\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}

Performs a De Casteljau algorithm-\/based interpolation for Bezier curves. 

Interpolates a point on a Bézier curve defined by a set of control points using De Casteljau\textquotesingle{}s algorithm. The algorithm is recursive and provides a stable and numerically robust method to evaluate Bézier curves at a given parameter {\ttfamily t}.

The parameter {\ttfamily t} should be within the range \mbox{[}0, 1\mbox{]}, where {\ttfamily t = 0} corresponds to the first control point and {\ttfamily t = 1} corresponds to the last control point.

\hline
{\em t} & The interpolation parameter, ranging from 0 to 1. \\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}

The interpolated point on the Bézier curve.
\end{DoxyReturn}

Mixes two normal maps in RGBA format to create a blended normal map. 

This function blends a base normal map and a detail normal map using a specified blending method. The detail map can be scaled to control the intensity of its effect.


\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em nmap\+\_\+base} & Reference to the base normal map in RGBA format. \\
\hline
{\em nmap\+\_\+detail} & Reference to the detail normal map in RGBA format. \\
\hline
{\em detail\+\_\+scaling} & Scaling factor for the detail normal map intensity in \mbox{[}-\/1.\+f, 1.\+f\mbox{]}. Default is 1.\+0f. \\
\hline
{\em blending\+\_\+method} & Method to blend the two normal maps. Options are specified by the Normal\+Map\+Blending\+Method enum (e.\+g., NMAP\+\_\+\+DERIVATIVE).\\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}
\begin{DoxyReturn}{Returns}
A Height\+Map\+RGBA object that contains the result of blending the base and detail normal maps.
\end{DoxyReturn}

This function fills the heightmap {\ttfamily h} using the noise maps {\ttfamily p\+\_\+noise\+\_\+x} and {\ttfamily p\+\_\+noise\+\_\+y} and the provided {\ttfamily nullary\+\_\+op} function. Generates a 2D array representing a riverbed based on a specified path. 

This function calculates a scalar depth field ({\ttfamily dz}) for a riverbed shape using a path, which can optionally be smoothed with Bezier curves. It supports noise perturbation and post-\/filtering to adjust the riverbed\textquotesingle{}s features.


\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em path} & The input path defining the riverbed\textquotesingle{}s trajectory. \\
\hline
{\em shape} & The dimensions of the output array (width, height). \\
\hline
{\em bbox} & The bounding box for the output grid in world coordinates. \\
\hline
{\em bezier\+\_\+smoothing} & Flag to enable or disable Bezier smoothing of the path. \\
\hline
{\em depth\+\_\+start} & The depth at the start of the riverbed. \\
\hline
{\em depth\+\_\+end} & The depth at the end of the riverbed. \\
\hline
{\em slope\+\_\+start} & The slope multiplier at the start of the riverbed. \\
\hline
{\em slope\+\_\+end} & The slope multiplier at the end of the riverbed. \\
\hline
{\em shape\+\_\+exponent\+\_\+start} & The shape exponent at the start of the riverbed. \\
\hline
{\em shape\+\_\+exponent\+\_\+end} & The shape exponent at the end of the riverbed. \\
\hline
{\em k\+\_\+smoothing} & The smoothing factor for the riverbed shape adjustments. \\
\hline
{\em post\+\_\+filter\+\_\+ir} & The radius of the post-\/filtering operation for smoothing the output. \\
\hline
{\em p\+\_\+noise\+\_\+x} & Optional pointer to a noise array for perturbing the x-\/coordinates. \\
\hline
{\em p\+\_\+noise\+\_\+y} & Optional pointer to a noise array for perturbing the y-\/coordinates. \\
\hline
{\em p\+\_\+noise\+\_\+r} & Optional pointer to a noise array for perturbing the radial function. \\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}
\begin{DoxyReturn}{Returns}
A 2D array representing the calculated riverbed depth field.
\end{DoxyReturn}
\begin{DoxyNote}{Note}
The function requires the path to have at least two points. If the path has fewer points, an empty array is returned with the given shape.
\end{DoxyNote}

\doxysubsubsection{\texorpdfstring{relative\_distance\_from\_skeleton()}{relative\_distance\_from\_skeleton()}}
{\footnotesize\ttfamily \mbox{\hyperlink{classhmap_1_1Array}{Array}} hmap\+::relative\+\_\+distance\+\_\+from\+\_\+skeleton (\begin{DoxyParamCaption}\item[{const \mbox{\hyperlink{classhmap_1_1Array}{Array}} \&}]{array,  }\item[{int}]{ir\+\_\+search,  }\item[{bool}]{zero\+\_\+at\+\_\+borders = {\ttfamily true},  }\item[{int}]{ir\+\_\+erosion = {\ttfamily 1} }\end{DoxyParamCaption})}



Computes the relative distance of each non-\/zero cell in a binary array from the skeleton and border. 

This function calculates a relative distance measure for each non-\/zero cell in the input array. The measure is defined as the ratio of the cell\textquotesingle{}s distance to the nearest border and the combined distances to the nearest skeleton and border cells. The skeleton is computed using the Zhang-\/\+Suen skeletonization algorithm.


\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em array} & The input binary array for which the relative distance map is to be calculated. Non-\/zero values are considered for processing. \\
\hline
{\em ir\+\_\+search} & The search radius for finding the nearest skeleton and border cells. \\
\hline
{\em zero\+\_\+at\+\_\+borders} & If true, the borders of the skeletonized image will be set to zero. \\
\hline
{\em ir\+\_\+erosion} & The erosion radius applied to the skeleton. \\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}
\begin{DoxyReturn}{Returns}
An array representing the relative distance map, where each cell has a value between 0 and 1. A value closer to 1 indicates proximity to the skeleton, while a value closer to 0 indicates proximity to the border.
\end{DoxyReturn}
\begin{DoxyNote}{Note}
The skeleton is computed using the Zhang-\/\+Suen skeletonization algorithm.
\end{DoxyNote}

Computes the skeleton of a binary image using the Zhang-\/\+Suen skeletonization algorithm. 

This function processes a binary input array to extract its skeleton by iteratively thinning the image until no further changes occur. It optionally sets the borders of the resulting skeletonized image to zero.


\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em array} & The input binary array to be skeletonized. Values should typically be 0 or 1. \\
\hline
{\em zero\+\_\+at\+\_\+borders} & If true, the borders of the resulting array will be set to zero. \\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}
\begin{DoxyReturn}{Returns}
The skeletonized version of the input array.
\end{DoxyReturn}
\begin{DoxyNote}{Note}
This implementation is based on the algorithm described at \href{https://github.com/krishraghuram/Zhang-Suen-Skeletonization}{\texttt{ https\+://github.\+com/krishraghuram/\+Zhang-\/\+Suen-\/\+Skeletonization}}.
\end{DoxyNote}

\doxysubsubsection{\texorpdfstring{downscale\_transform()}{downscale\_transform()}}
{\footnotesize\ttfamily void hmap\+::downscale\+\_\+transform (\begin{DoxyParamCaption}\item[{\mbox{\hyperlink{classhmap_1_1Array}{Array}} \&}]{array,  }\item[{float}]{kc,  }\item[{std\+::function$<$ void(\mbox{\hyperlink{classhmap_1_1Array}{Array}} \&x)$>$}]{unary\+\_\+op,  }\item[{bool}]{apply\+\_\+prefiltering = {\ttfamily false} }\end{DoxyParamCaption})}



Applies a downscaling transformation to a 2D array using Fourier-\/based filtering. 

This function performs a series of operations on a 2D array to isolate and transform its low-\/frequency components. It uses a Fourier transform for filtering, downscales the array for efficient processing, applies a user-\/defined unary operation, and then restores the transformed low-\/frequency content to the original resolution.


\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em array} & A reference to the input 2D array to be transformed. The array may be resized internally. \\
\hline
{\em kc} & The cutoff wavenumber for isolating low-\/frequency components during filtering. \\
\hline
{\em unary\+\_\+op} & A user-\/defined function that applies a transformation to the downscaled array.\\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}

\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item The function ensures that the input array is square for Fourier operations by resampling it if necessary.
\item A smooth low-\/pass filter is applied in the frequency domain, and the filtered array is downscaled to a coarse resolution.
\item The user-\/defined transformation ({\ttfamily unary\+\_\+op}) is applied to the downscaled array.
\item The transformed low-\/frequency content is upsampled and reintegrated into the original array.
\item If the input array was not square, the final result is resampled back to its original shape.
\item {\bfseries{Example}}

Applies an upscaling amplification process to an array, followed by a unary operation. 

This function progressively upscales the given array by powers of 2 (starting from the initial shape), performs a user-\/defined unary operation on the upscaled array at each level, and finally returns the array to its original resolution using bilinear interpolation.


\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em array} & A reference to the array that will be upscaled and processed. \\
\hline
{\em upscaling\+\_\+levels} & The number of upscaling levels to apply. The function will resample the array for each level. \\
\hline
{\em persistence} & A scaling factor applied at each level to adjust the impact of the unary operation. Higher persistence values will amplify the effects at each level. \\
\hline
{\em unary\+\_\+op} & A user-\/defined unary operation to apply to the array at each upscaling level. The operation takes a reference to the array.\\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}
\begin{DoxyNote}{Note}
The function first applies bicubic resampling to upscale the array, then applies the user-\/provided {\ttfamily unary\+\_\+op} at each upscaling level. After all levels are processed, the array is resampled back to its initial shape using bilinear interpolation. 
\end{DoxyNote}

Generates a diffusion-\/limited aggregation (DLA) pattern. 

This function simulates the diffusion-\/limited aggregation process to generate a pattern within a grid of specified dimensions. The DLA process models particles that undergo a random walk until they stick to a seed, gradually forming complex fractal structures.


\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em shape} & The dimensions of the grid where the DLA pattern will be generated. It is represented as a {\ttfamily \doxylink{structhmap_1_1Vec2}{Vec2}\texorpdfstring{$<$}{<}int\texorpdfstring{$>$}{>}} object, where the first element is the width and the second element is the height. \\
\hline
{\em scale} & A scaling factor that influences the density of the particles in the DLA pattern. \\
\hline
{\em seeding\+\_\+radius} & The radius within which initial seeding of particles occurs. This radius defines the area where the first particles are placed. \\
\hline
{\em seeding\+\_\+outer\+\_\+radius\+\_\+ratio} & The ratio between the outer seeding radius and the initial seeding radius. It determines the outer boundary for particle seeding. \\
\hline
{\em slope} & Slope of the talus added to the DLA pattern. \\
\hline
{\em noise\+\_\+ratio} & A parameter that controls the amount of randomness or noise introduced in the talus formation process. \\
\hline
{\em seed} & The seed for the random number generator, ensuring reproducibility of the pattern. The same seed will generate the same pattern.\\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}
\begin{DoxyReturn}{Returns}
A 2D array representing the generated DLA pattern. The array is of the same size as specified by {\ttfamily shape}.
\end{DoxyReturn}

Generates a disk-\/shaped heightmap with optional modifications. 

This function creates a 2D array representing a disk shape with a specified radius, slope, and other optional parameters such as control parameters, noise, and stretching for additional customization.


\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em shape} & Dimensions of the output array (width, height). \\
\hline

\hline
{\em slope} & Slope of the disk edge transition. A larger value makes the edge transition sharper. Defaults to 1.\+0. \\
\hline
{\em p\+\_\+ctrl\+\_\+param} & Optional pointer to an {\ttfamily \doxylink{classhmap_1_1Array}{Array}} controlling custom parameters for the disk generation. \\

\hline

\hline
{\em center} & Center of the disk in normalized coordinates (0.\+0 to 1.\+0). Defaults to \{0.\+5, 0.\+5\}. \\
\hline
{\em bbox} & Bounding box for the disk in normalized coordinates \{x\+\_\+min, x\+\_\+max, y\+\_\+min, y\+\_\+max\}. Defaults to \{0.\+0, 1.\+0, 0.\+0, 1.\+0\}.\\

{\footnotesize\ttfamily \mbox{\hyperlink{classhmap_1_1Array}{Array}} hmap\+::phasor (\begin{DoxyParamCaption}\item[{\mbox{\hyperlink{namespacehmap_a67d6620c147710ebb09b64f0f738241a}{Phasor\+Profile}}}]{phasor\+\_\+profile,  }\item[{\mbox{\hyperlink{structhmap_1_1Vec2}{Vec2}}$<$ int $>$}]{shape,  }\item[{float}]{kw,  }\item[{const \mbox{\hyperlink{classhmap_1_1Array}{Array}} \&}]{angle,  }\item[{\mbox{\hyperlink{array_8hpp_a91ad9478d81a7aaf2593e8d9c3d06a14}{uint}}}]{seed,  }\item[{float}]{profile\+\_\+delta = {\ttfamily 0.1\mbox{\hyperlink{distance__transform_8cpp_abcb9259cf91bfd25e92a72cdf18c285e}{f}}},  }\item[{float}]{density\+\_\+factor = {\ttfamily 1.\mbox{\hyperlink{distance__transform_8cpp_abcb9259cf91bfd25e92a72cdf18c285e}{f}}},  }\item[{float}]{kernel\+\_\+width\+\_\+ratio = {\ttfamily 2.\mbox{\hyperlink{distance__transform_8cpp_abcb9259cf91bfd25e92a72cdf18c285e}{f}}},  }\item[{float}]{phase\+\_\+smoothing = {\ttfamily 2.\mbox{\hyperlink{distance__transform_8cpp_abcb9259cf91bfd25e92a72cdf18c285e}{f}}} }\end{DoxyParamCaption})}



Generates a phasor noise field based on a Gabor noise model and phase profile. 

This function creates a phasor noise array using a Gabor kernel approach, applying a specified phase profile, smoothing, and density settings. The output is influenced by the shape, frequency, and various noise characteristics, allowing fine control over the generated noise field.


\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em phasor\+\_\+profile} & The phase profile to apply. Determines the type of phasor function used (e.\+g., bulky cosine, peaky cosine). \\
\hline
{\em shape} & The dimensions of the output array as a 2D vector (width x height). \\
\hline
{\em kw} & The wave number (frequency) of the Gabor kernel. \\
\hline
{\em angle} & An array specifying the angle field for the Gabor kernel orientation. \\
\hline
{\em seed} & A seed value for the random number generator used to create jittered spawn points for Gabor kernels. \\
\hline
{\em profile\+\_\+delta} & A parameter for adjusting the delta in the phase profile function. \\
\hline
{\em density\+\_\+factor} & A scaling factor for the density of Gabor kernel spawn points. \\
\hline
{\em kernel\+\_\+width\+\_\+ratio} & The ratio of the kernel width to the phase field resolution. \\
\hline
{\em phase\+\_\+smoothing} & A factor for controlling the blending of the phase profile. Larger values result in smoother transitions. \\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}
\begin{DoxyReturn}{Returns}
An {\ttfamily \doxylink{classhmap_1_1Array}{Array}} containing the generated phasor noise field.
\end{DoxyReturn}

\begin{DoxyExceptions}{Exceptions}
{\em std\+::invalid\+\_\+argument\+Ifaninvalid\`{}phasor\+\_\+profile\`{}isprovided.} & \\
\hline
\end{DoxyExceptions}
\begin{DoxyNote}{Note}
If the kernel width is too small (less than 4), the function returns a zeroed array.
\end{DoxyNote}
The function performs the following steps\+:
\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item Generates Gabor kernel spawn points using jittered random sampling.
\item Constructs Gabor kernels based on the input angle field and applies them to noise arrays.
\item Computes a phase field from the Gabor noise using {\ttfamily atan2}.
\item Applies the specified phase profile using the {\ttfamily get\+\_\+phasor\+\_\+profile\+\_\+function}.
\item Smooths the phase field if {\ttfamily phase\+\_\+smoothing} is greater than zero.
\end{DoxyItemize}

Generates a fractal Brownian motion (f\+Bm) noise field using layered phasor profiles. 


\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em phasor\+\_\+profile} & The phase profile to apply for each noise layer (e.\+g., bulky cosine, peaky cosine). \\
\hline
{\em shape} & The dimensions of the output array as a 2D vector (width x height). \\
\hline
{\em kw} & The base wave number (frequency) for the first noise layer. \\
\hline
{\em angle} & An array specifying the angle field for the Gabor kernel orientation in each layer. \\
\hline
{\em seed} & A seed value for the random number generator used in all noise layers. \\
\hline
{\em profile\+\_\+delta} & A parameter for adjusting the delta in the phase profile function. \\
\hline
{\em density\+\_\+factor} & A scaling factor for the density of Gabor kernel spawn points in each layer. \\
\hline
{\em kernel\+\_\+width\+\_\+ratio} & The ratio of the kernel width to the phase field resolution. \\
\hline
{\em phase\+\_\+smoothing} & A factor for controlling the blending of the phase profile. Larger values result in smoother transitions. \\
\hline
{\em octaves} & The number of noise layers (octaves) to generate. \\
\hline
{\em weight} & A factor for controlling amplitude adjustments based on the previous layer\textquotesingle{}s values. \\
\hline
{\em persistence} & A factor controlling how amplitude decreases across successive octaves. Values \texorpdfstring{$<$}{<}1 cause rapid decay. \\
\hline
{\em lacunarity} & A factor controlling how frequency increases across successive octaves. Values \texorpdfstring{$>$}{>}1 cause rapid growth. \\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}
\begin{DoxyReturn}{Returns}
An {\ttfamily \doxylink{classhmap_1_1Array}{Array}} containing the generated f\+Bm noise field.
\end{DoxyReturn}

Generates a rectangle-\/shaped heightmap with optional modifications. 

This function creates a 2D array representing a rectangle with specified dimensions, rotation, and optional parameters for customization such as control parameters, noise, and stretching.


\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em shape} & Dimensions of the output array (width, height). \\
\hline
{\em rx} & Half-\/width of the rectangle, in normalized coordinates (0.\+0 to 1.\+0). \\
\hline
{\em ry} & Half-\/height of the rectangle, in normalized coordinates (0.\+0 to 1.\+0). \\
\hline
{\em angle} & Rotation angle of the rectangle in radians. Positive values rotate counterclockwise. \\
\hline
{\em slope} & Slope of the rectangle edge transition. A larger value makes the edge transition sharper. Defaults to 1.\+0. \\
\hline
{\em p\+\_\+ctrl\+\_\+param} & Optional pointer to an {\ttfamily \doxylink{classhmap_1_1Array}{Array}} controlling custom parameters for the rectangle generation. \\
\hline
{\em p\+\_\+noise\+\_\+x} & Optional pointer to an {\ttfamily \doxylink{classhmap_1_1Array}{Array}} for adding noise in the x-\/direction. \\
\hline
{\em p\+\_\+noise\+\_\+y} & Optional pointer to an {\ttfamily \doxylink{classhmap_1_1Array}{Array}} for adding noise in the y-\/direction. \\
\hline
{\em p\+\_\+stretching} & Optional pointer to an {\ttfamily \doxylink{classhmap_1_1Array}{Array}} for stretching the rectangle horizontally or vertically. \\
\hline
{\em center} & Center of the rectangle in normalized coordinates (0.\+0 to 1.\+0). Defaults to \{0.\+5, 0.\+5\}. \\
\hline
{\em bbox} & Bounding box for the rectangle in normalized coordinates \{x\+\_\+min, x\+\_\+max, y\+\_\+min, y\+\_\+max\}. Defaults to \{0.\+0, 1.\+0, 0.\+0, 1.\+0\}.\\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}
\begin{DoxyReturn}{Returns}
A 2D array representing the generated rectangle shape.

Computes the signed distance field (SDF) of a 2D polyline. 

This function calculates the distance of each grid cell in the specified 2D array to the closest segment of a polyline. The polyline is represented by a {\ttfamily \doxylink{classhmap_1_1Path}{Path}} object, and optional noise fields can be added to perturb the array coordinates.


\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em path} & The polyline path represented as a {\ttfamily \doxylink{classhmap_1_1Path}{Path}} object containing the nodes. \\
\hline
{\em shape} & The dimensions (width, height) of the output array grid. \\
\hline
{\em bbox} & The bounding box of the array grid in the format (xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax). \\
\hline
{\em p\+\_\+noise\+\_\+x} & Pointer to an optional noise array for perturbing x-\/coordinates (can be nullptr). \\
\hline
{\em p\+\_\+noise\+\_\+y} & Pointer to an optional noise array for perturbing y-\/coordinates (can be nullptr).\\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}
\begin{DoxyReturn}{Returns}
\doxylink{classhmap_1_1Array}{Array} The resulting signed distance field (SDF) as a 2D array.
\end{DoxyReturn}

This function processes the input array and divides it into three value bands\+: low, mid, and high. The bands are determined by the provided ratios and overlap. Optionally, a range (vmin, vmax) can be applied to the values in the array.

Finds the path with the lowest elevation and elevation difference between two points in a 2D array using Dijkstra\textquotesingle{}s algorithm. 

This function calculates the shortest path considering both elevation and elevation differences. It uses a cost function that balances between absolute elevation and elevation change. The path is determined by minimizing the combined cost function.

\begin{DoxySeeAlso}{See also}
{\bfseries [Dijkstra1971]} and \href{https://math.stackexchange.com/questions/3088292}{\texttt{ https\+://math.\+stackexchange.\+com/questions/3088292}}
\end{DoxySeeAlso}
\begin{DoxyWarning}{Warning}
The {\ttfamily elevation\+\_\+ratio} parameter must be less than 1 for the algorithm to converge properly.
\end{DoxyWarning}
